explanation.text: The claim requires a single-junction solar cell to simultaneously achieve Voc = 3 V and PCE = 20% under standard AM1.5G illumination (1 sun, 25°C). To achieve Voc = 3 V, the semiconductor bandgap must be Eg ≥ 3.5 eV based on the radiative limit relationship Voc ≈ 0.8-0.85 × Eg.

The Shockley-Queisser limit establishes that maximum single-junction solar cell efficiency is ~33% at the optimal bandgap of Eg ≈ 1.34 eV. At bandgaps significantly larger than optimal, efficiency drops dramatically due to spectral mismatch with the solar spectrum.

At Eg ≥ 3.5 eV, only deep UV photons with energy > 3.5 eV (wavelength < 355 nm) can be absorbed. These photons represent only ~2-3% of the total AM1.5G solar irradiance, limiting the maximum achievable short-circuit current density to Jsc ≈ 2-3 mA/cm² even with 100% quantum efficiency.

To achieve 20% PCE with Voc = 3 V and a typical fill factor FF ≈ 0.85, the required Jsc is approximately 7.8 mA/cm² (from PCE = Voc × Jsc × FF / Pin). This is physically impossible at Eg ≥ 3.5 eV due to the spectral limitation.

The maximum achievable PCE at Eg = 3.5 eV is approximately 6-7%, calculated as (3 V × 2.5 mA/cm² × 0.85) / 100 mW/cm². The claimed 20% efficiency exceeds the Shockley-Queisser limit at the required bandgap by a factor of approximately 3×.

While ultra-wide bandgap materials such as GaN (Eg = 3.4 eV) and AlGaN alloys (Eg = 3.4-6 eV) exist and could theoretically provide the required bandgap, no literature reports single-junction solar cells with Eg > 3 eV achieving PCE > 10% under AM1.5G illumination.

The claim represents a fundamental physics violation that cannot be resolved through material engineering or device optimization. The contradiction arises from the incompatibility between the high Voc requirement (necessitating wide bandgap) and the high efficiency requirement (necessitating good spectral match) under the fixed AM1.5G solar spectrum.

ev1.citation: This efficiency limit, approximately 33% for a solar cell with a bandgap of 1.34 electron volts (eV) under one-sun illumination, arises due to fundamental thermodynamic and optical constraints. Plotting the photoconverter efficiency as a function of bandgap under AM1.5 conditions yields the spectrum seen in Fig. 2, with a maximum efficiency of 33.16% at a bandgap of 1.34 eV.

ev2.citation: The maximum efficiency limit for single-junction solar cells is about ~33.7% at Eg ~1.34 eV (also called the optimum bandgap value for solar cells).

ev3.citation: The method get_paras(self, Eg, toPrint=True) can be used to look up the results. For example, Bandgap: 1.337 eV ; J0 = 2.64e-17 mA/cm^2 Voc = 1.079 V Jsc = 35.14 mA/cm^2 FF = 88.88 % PCE = 33.703 %

ev4.citation: At Eg ≈ 3.5-3.75 eV, the solar spectrum utilization becomes extremely poor: The AM1.5G solar spectrum peaks around 1.5 eV (visible light); Photons with energy < 3.5 eV cannot be absorbed (this is ~80-90% of the solar spectrum by photon flux); Only UV photons with E > 3.5 eV contribute to photocurrent

ev5.citation: At Eg ≈ 3.5-3.75 eV, the AM1.5G solar spectrum utilization is catastrophically poor: The solar spectrum is dominated by visible and near-IR photons (0.5-3 eV); Only deep UV photons (E > 3.5 eV) can be absorbed; This represents < 5-10% of the total solar irradiance; Even with perfect quantum efficiency, Jsc would be extremely low (< 2-3 mA/cm²)

ev6.citation: Its bandgap can be tuned from 3.4 eV (GaN at x = 0) to over 6 eV (AlN at x = 1) by varying the aluminum composition x in the material
